headline: What should Arizona governor and legislative candidates be saying about water?
author: Joanna Allhands
sentences: Lake says that Arizona should work with the federal government, other states and Mexico to invest in desalination as a long-term solution, while working on shorter-term solutions like increasing our capacity to store water on the Salt and Verde rivers, capturing more storm runoff and expanding water recycling and reuse.

Even if water doesn’t become a major talking point in 2022, candidates better spend some time boning up on the basics and articulating not only where they stand on key issues, such as how and where we grow (and who pays for it), but how they would balance a billion competing interests with valid uses for water.

A lot could happen with water on their watch
Big, thorny water issues are going to arise in the next few years, and if the next governor and Legislature aren’t anticipating them, they are going to get slapped with even tougher choices and lousy solutions.

We need elected leaders who can build coalitions and find compromises, a governor and Legislature that is willing to tackle water issues head on instead of kicking the can.
Some bills have been proposed this session to address that, but more are expected – particularly as problems in Pinal replicate in parts of metro Phoenix in coming years.
Residential wells are already going dry in some rural areas, and the Pinal Active Management Area has been told that it can no longer grow solely on groundwater.
The next governor may not be intimately involved in this work, but whoever he or she appoints as director of the Arizona Department of Water Resources will.
